title: Igor Kordej
text:
Igor Kordej (referred to as Igor Kordey in American and French publications; born 23 June 1957) is a <a href="croats">Croatian</a> <a href="comic%20book%20artist">comic book artist</a>, <a href="illustrator">illustrator</a>, <a href="graphic%20designer">graphic designer</a> and <a href="scenographer">scenographer</a> of international reputation.
Career.
Education.
Graduated at ŠPUD (The School of Applied Arts and Design in Zagreb), graphic department (1972-1977) and attended two years at <a href="Academy%20of%20Fine%20Arts%2C%20University%20of%20Zagreb">Academy of Fine Arts, University of Zagreb</a>, graphic department (1977-1979).
Novi kvadrat.
Igor Kordej started as a professional graphic designer when he was 18, and as a professional comic artist and illustrator when he was 19 years old, joining a very influential group of comic artists "Novi kvadrat" (New square) 1976–1979, and publishing in all relevant Yugoslavian youth magazines of that era. In 1979 "Novi kvadrat" won the prestigious national award "7 sekretara SKOJ-a", thus marking a break-up of the group.
SLS studio.
At the beginning of the eighties Kordej teams-up with <a href="Mirko%20Ili%C4%87">Mirko Ilić</a> again in SLS studio (acronym for "Slow, Bad and Expensive"), and focuses on producing album covers and posters for Yugoslavian pop musicians and groups. After the break-up with Ilić he continues with solo career, doing illustration for Yugoslavian mainstream magazines, film and theater posters, logotypes and album covers.
Early international work.
He started a career in European comic market in 1986 (France, Spain, Germany), and since 1989 on the US market (<a href="Heavy%20Metal%20Magazine">Heavy Metal Magazine</a>). His most significant work from that period is album "Les cinq saisons – Automne", published in 1990 by <a href="Dargaud">Dargaud</a>. That album was appointed by the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Culture%20%28France%29">Ministry of Culture in France</a> as a work of significant cultural value and was assigned to all public libraries in France (in 2011 the same album was featured in <a href="Paul%20Gravett">Paul Gravett</a>'s book "1001 Comics You Must Read Before You Die").
Kordej moves from Zagreb to a small Istrian village, <a href="Groznjan">Groznjan</a> in 1988 where he leads, as an artist and supervisor, a group of over 20 artists and story writers (among others a young <a href="Darko%20Macan">Darko Macan</a>, <a href="Edvin%20Biukovi%C4%87">Edvin Biuković</a> and <a href="Goran%20Sud%C5%BEuka">Goran Sudžuka</a>), as well as veterans Radovan Devlić and Dragan Filipović Fipa, producing comics and design for the German market.
Moving abroad.
He moves to <a href="Denmark">Denmark</a> in 1991, invited by <a href="Semic%20Press">Semic International</a> company, where he spends almost a year, producing comics and illustrations for <a href="Malibu%20Comics">Malibu Comics</a>.
In 1997 he moves to <a href="Canada">Canada</a>, invited by <a href="Digital%20Chameleon">Digital Chameleon</a> company, working as a creative director. Having disputes with management, he leaves the company after eight months and becomes a <a href="freelancer">freelancer</a> again.
Marvel.
His career in <a href="Marvel%20Comics">Marvel Comics</a> can be divided in two phases; the first one (when he simultaneously worked for <a href="Dark%20Horse%20Comics">Dark Horse Comics</a>) is from 1994 to 1996, under editor-in-chief <a href="Marcus%20McLaurin">Marcus McLaurin</a>, when Kordej produced several hand-painted comics for "Tales of Marvels" series. The second phase began in 2001 when he was invited by editor-in–chief <a href="Joe%20Quesada">Joe Quesada</a>, to work on <a href="Cable%20%28comics%29">Cable</a> series, as well as <a href="New%20X-Men">New X-Men</a> series. Shortly after <a href="9/11%20attacks">9/11 attacks</a> many of Marvel artists produced illustrations inspired by the tragedy. They all went on public auction, with all profit given to families of fallen rescuers. Kordey's illustration "Pennsylvania Plane" was bought by <a href="The%20Library%20of%20Congress">The Library of Congress</a>. Because of his speed as an artist, at his peak, Kordej was producing artwork for three or four monthly books at the same time. However, as a result, he has attracted heavy criticism for the quality of his art, especially from the readers. Eventually he got fired from Marvel in April 2004.
Delcourt.
However, that event opened up a new chapter in Kordey's career. Just a few months later he signed his first contracts with <a href="Delcourt%20%28publisher%29">Editions Delcourt</a>, and his prolific collaboration with that French publisher continued until nowadays. In a period of fifteen years, producing 4-5 albums per year, concluding with 2019 he published close to seventy albums on francophone market, out of which only series sold out over 1,000.000 copies.
In 2006 he moves back to his homeland.
Style and recognition.
Throughout all those years Kordej continued to produce graphic design and illustrations for both francophone and ex-Yugoslavian region markets, occasionally doing illustrations for US comics market.
He has a very diverse repertoire, moving between traditional pencils and inks to fully painted panels, using <a href="watercolors">watercolors</a> and <a href="gouache">gouache</a>.
His works are collected, among others, in <a href="The%20Library%20of%20Congress">The Library of Congress</a>, <a href="LucasFilm">LucasFilm</a> (CA) and <a href="MoMa">MoMa</a> – Museum od Modern Art (NY).
